Crime_Name: Jeopardy Order under Income Tax Act
Legal_Issue: Did the Minister have reasonable grounds to believe that delay in collection would jeopardize the assessed tax debt?
Governing_Law: Subsection 225.2(2) of the Income Tax Act
Application_Facts: Mrs. Reddy was assessed $461,285.86 in taxes due to transfers from her son's account.
Decision_Outcome: The Jeopardy Order is upheld as the Minister met the required test under subsection 225.2(2).
Remedy_Requested: Mrs. Reddy sought review under subsection 225.2(8) to set aside the Jeopardy Order.
Court_Ruling: Application to set aside the Jeopardy Order dismissed with costs.
Defendant_Behavior: Mrs. Reddy challenged the Jeopardy Order, arguing insufficient disclosure and misrepresentation of her financial situation.
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged insufficient disclosure and misrepresentation of financial situation.
Legal_Standard: Reasonable grounds to believe collection would be jeopardized by delay.
Procedural_Issue: Ex parte application by the Minister led to the Jeopardy Order.
Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Fowles' affidavit provided credible evidence; Mrs. Reddy failed to raise reasonable doubt.
Evidence_Used: Affidavit of Mr. Fowles showing potential asset transfer or liquidation.
Legal_Provision_Cited: Subsection 225.2(2) and subsection 225.2(8) of the Income Tax Act
Application_Basis: Risk of delay in tax collection due to possible asset dissipation.
Evidence_Assessed: Affidavit evidence on financial risk and asset movement.
Relief_Sought: To set aside the Jeopardy Order.
Governing_Rule: Subsection 225.2(2) requires judicial authorization if there are reasonable grounds for jeopardy in collection.
Outcome: Jeopardy Order upheld; application to set aside dismissed with costs.
Harm_Assessment: Potential harm from delayed tax collection due to asset transfer.
Cause_Description: Mrs. Reddy was assessed $461,285.86 in taxes due to transfers from her son's account.
Evidence_Handling: Court relied on Mr. Fowles' affidavit; no sufficient rebuttal from Mrs. Reddy.
Legal_Provision_Violated: None found; Minister acted within authority under subsection 225.2(2).
Evidence_Issues: Mrs. Reddy alleged misrepresentation but failed to substantiate.
Misrepresentation_Element: Mrs. Reddy alleged misrepresentation of her financial situation.
Legal_Provision: Subsection 225.2(2) and (8) of the Income Tax Act
Evidence_Assessment: Affidavit evidence deemed credible; challenger did not raise reasonable doubt.
Decision_Rationale: Minister had reasonable grounds for believing collection would be jeopardized by delay.
Evidentiary_Issues: Insufficient evidence from Mrs. Reddy to challenge the affidavit.
